description: Fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions.
name: ORGANIC CHEMISTRY I

values.comments:
This class is a fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern
concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions
The course itself was described as a mostly memorization. Few students
commented on the content of the course itself, but rather the necessity of it for pre-med
students.
Students presented mixed reviews about the professor. Some students found
Professor Walsh to be a good professor, despite what other reviews about him said.
Others found that he had a rude demeanor and often stated that he would rather be
teaching at another school. Students stressed the importance of office hours and the
usefulness of them.
All students stressed the difficulty of organic chemistry had been akin to the
rumors that they had heard. This course requires a major time commitment from the
students and that there were “long hours outside of class reading and doing problems.”
Students expressed the unfairness of curving to a C, which was especially difficult for
those on the low end of the grading spectrum. This course is recommended for Pre-med
students and majors.

This is a fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern concepts of
structure and mechanism of reactions.
Students seem to have found the course material interesting but overwhelming at
times due to its “fast pace.” Many appreciated that the course focused less on
memorization and more on “reasoning and application skills.”
Most students greatly enjoyed Professor Winkler’s teaching. They praised his
passion and enthusiasm, and his ability to present potentially dull material in an
“engaging” manner. Many also found Professor Winkler’s “near constant availability”
very helpful.
Overall students found that the course took considerable daily practice to perform
well on the exams. Most would not recommend this course unless required due to its
difficulty.

This is a fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern
concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions.
Overall students thought this class was interesting and often commented that it
covered a “difficult subject.” One student said, “I know that I've learned the material” as
opposed to just having memorized it, and this would come in handy for taking the MCAT
later on. Students complained about the meeting time of the course, saying that it should
be split up into smaller chunks of time.
Students raved about professor Schmink. He was “very energetic” and an
“outstanding instructor.” He was able to “carefully and concisely articulate concepts,”
which were difficult, so that they were “readily understood.” Professor Schmink made
“immediate concrete changes” to his teaching style when students responded to
evaluations he distributed. Professor Schmink “really care[d] about teaching and the
material” and was available to help students out as much as possible.
The course was very difficult, but this was “only attributable to the material
itself.”
